etymology.description: 一 ‘one/entire’ + 切 ‘all; the whole’ = everything; all.
etymology.interpretation: Combines numeral 一 with classical 切 meaning “all/every” to denote the totality of things without exception. Common in both literary and modern usage for “everything; all.”

examples.chinese: 请把一切准备好(請把一切準備好)。
他愿意为你放弃一切(他願意為你放棄一切)。
examples.pinyin: Tā yuànyì wèi nǐ fàngqì yíqiè.
examples.english: He is willing to give up everything for you.

examples.chinese: 面对困难时(面對困難時)，我们要相信一切都会好起来(我們要相信一切都會好起來)。
examples.pinyin: Miànduì kùnnan shí, wǒmen yào xiāngxìn yíqiè dōu huì hǎo qǐlái.
examples.english: When facing difficulties, we should believe that everything will get better.
